sub_title: Associate Director of International Accreditation, Council for International Schools
summary:
Chris Durbin is substantive Associate Director for School Support and Evaluation (SEE) for the Council of International School (CIS) based in Leiden, The Netherlands.  He recently acted in the role of Director of International Accreditation leading a global team of School Support and Evaluation Officers across the world. He has a responsibility for coordination of development work on the accreditation process. 
Prior to this, he worked as a School Development Adviser for the English Schools Foundation (ESF) in Hong Kong, where he was responsible for quality assurance, strategic curriculum and professional development for 7 secondary schools. He was involved in recruitment, induction and professional review and development of  principals of kindergarten, primary, special, secondary and all-through schools. He managed and developed a review process for the ESF Higher Education Counselling Network.  
Earlier in his career, Chris worked in education in the UK as a local education authority inspector/advisor,  and before that, with BBC Education as an Education Officer. In both positions, he developed a European-wide reputation for geographical and historical education and contributed to many Council of Europe conferences.  He has been an adviser and a trustee of TIDE [Teachers in Development Education, Birmingham] and the Living Earth Foundation where he contributed to and edited many publications and delivered workshops. 
A lifelong environmentalist and cyclist, he enjoys nothing more than a day in the wilderness or a 100 km ride.  He has twice ompleted a cycle ride from London to Paris raising money for myeloma research. 

A leader who develops educational communities with a deep sense of commitment to making the world a better place for future generations.

education.grade: Distinction and award for best student teacher

awards.title: Gold Award - Mapzone GIS Missions
awards.description:
These were fun interactive mini games to explain Geographical Information Systems
http://mapzone.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/mapzone/giszone/english/gismissions/

awards.title: Gold Award for  Staffordshire Learning Net
awards.description:
This was at the time the most used website for geography teachers in the UK and beyond.
http//www.sln.org.uk/geography

awards.title: Gold Award for Teaching Pack Japan 2000
awards.description: Japan 2000 was a BBC educational TV series which I advised on and I developed a teaching pack that had bilingual elements - enabling students to work with Japanese characters on maps,

projects.title: ESF Masarang - A passion for reading through environmental education
projects.description: With Adrienne of Masarang Hong Kong, we conceived a Hong Kong local teachers project to develop reading in English skills.  A group of teachers from ESF who are either EAL or Environmental Educators or both have devised a project that involves four professional development sessions.  We are currently half way through this project.

contributors.headline: Associate Director of International Accreditation, Council for International Schools

projects.title: Curriculum Development for Years 12 and 13 ESF
projects.description: This is a development of the ESF Diploma Pathways that Diane Bohm started when she was a Post-16 Consultant here at ESF.  The project is about a continuum of education for years 12 and 13. It is an inclusive and personalized framework which allows students to select an appropriate pathway. The Applied Learning Pathway is one which we are particularly proud - it provides a pre-university route for students to achieve using BTEC qualifications.  This work was celebrated in 2014.  www.esfeducation.com/alc

contributors.headline: Associate Director of International Accreditation, Council for International Schools
Vice Principal at ESF Hong Kong

projects.title: Curriculum Continuum
projects.description: The purpose of this project is to develop an agreed view of learning and what really matters in ESF schools. This supports an understanding of our own identity and our own stated values and vision for learning in the global city of Hong Kong.

contributors.headline: Associate Director of International Accreditation, Council for International Schools
Global Director of Education, International. Education in Motion

projects.title: Developing Higher Education Opportunities
projects.description: This project is designed to improve the range of opportunities for ESF students in progression.  It starts from the premise that all students matter.  The goals evolve over time. A few years ago there was an emphasis on improving relationships and opportunities in Hong Kong and we are now looking for more affordable opportunities across Asia. We were successful and a number of our students attending HK universities rose from 8% to 24%.  In recent years, we were engaged in diversification of opportunities across the world for our applied learning pathway students.  The impact of this is evident with more and more BTEC students attending colleges outside the UK.  We are currently improving recognition of ESF in North American Universities systematically.

profile_positions.description:
Chris Durbin is an Associate Director for School Support and Evaluation (SS&E) based in Leiden, The Netherlands.  He is currently responsible for 40 member and accredited schools in Asia and Africa. He will be taking the lead on developing relationships with educators who volunteer for CIS and is the SS&E link to CIS Higher Education Services.   

Prior to this, he worked as a School Development Adviser for the English Schools Foundation (ESF) in Hong Kong, where he was responsible for quality assurance, strategic curriculum and professional development for 7 secondary schools. He was involved in recruitment, induction and professional review and development of  principals of kindergarten, primary, special, secondary and all-through schools. He managed and developed a review process for the ESF Higher Education Counselling Network.  

Earlier in his career, Chris worked in education in the UK as a local education authority inspector/advisor,  and before that, with BBC Education as an Education Officer. In both positions, he developed a European-wide reputation for geographical and historical education and contributed to many Council of Europe conferences.  He has been an adviser and a trustee of TIDE [Teachers in Development Education, Birmingham] and the Living Earth Foundation where he contributed to and edited many publications and delivered workshops. 

A lifelong environmentalist and cyclist, he enjoys nothing more than a day in the wilderness or a 100 km ride.  He recently completed a cycle ride from London to Paris raising money for myeloma research. A leader who develops educational communities with a deep sense of commitment to making the world a better place for future generations;
profile_positions.title: Associate Director of School Support and Evaluation
School Development Adviser

profile_positions.description: I was very honoured to serve in a team of advisers and inspectors in this county in the midlands of the UK. I became an Ofsted inspector. In working alongside Andy Holt, a web developer, and my colleague, Kate Russell my fellow adviser, I conceived www.sln.org.uk/geography a web site where geography teachers worldwide could share ideas and and share creative resources. It's growth was exponential. My greatest pride is that the community keep it going even though I have been gone 10 years. The site was the proud winner of Geographical Association Gold Award.
profile_positions.title: County Inspector for Humanities

profile_positions.description: I worked in a great team of education officers advising producers on educational media, video, audio and websites.  It was a time when the world wide web was new.  The BBC website was established and I was lucky enough to project manage the first iteration of GCSE Bitesize on line.
profile_positions.title: Education Officer, BBC Education [BBC Learning]

volunteer_experiences.description: As part of my role in ESF, I develop opportunities for ESF students to change the world for the better. I met Dr Willie Smits in 2010 and he was an inspiring scientist who recognises the importance of the rain forests of SE Asia and  the wildlife in particular.  I give of my time to encourage young people to go beyond the academic - social entrepreneurs have been significant in the world of environmental protection. They deserve our support.
